title: The CEO’s Playbook for Team Feedback That Delivers Results
description: CEOs set the tone for their companies. By modeling personal input and follow-up, you create a culture where feedback is normal and growth is expected.
content:
How can people work together to help one another succeed? It’s a deceptively simple question, and one of the most powerful tools you have as a CEO. Imagine introducing a practice of you and your senior leaders each identifying one specific, observable behavior to improve yourselves. These are concrete actions such as “end every meeting with agreed next steps” or “pause before responding to tough questions.” You choose which actions to prioritize by blending what matters most to you with what your colleagues say would make the biggest difference for them.

Set the tone at the top. When you, as CEO, go first—inviting feedback, listening without defensiveness, and adding your own insight to the mix—you give your team permission to do the same. This is the essence of stakeholder-centered coaching, a process pioneered by Marshall Goldsmith and colleagues. It combines external feedback from those affected by your leadership with your own internal clarity about what matters most right now. That combination produces goals that are both meaningful and doable. Once you’ve set your personal focus, share it openly and ask a few people to watch for it in action. Follow up periodically, with check-in statements such as “I’ve been working on my communication—what are you noticing about it?” These brief exchanges keep the process alive and send a clear signal—progress matters, feedback is welcome, and everyone is accountable for their own growth. Throughout time, this becomes less “the CEO’s latest project” and more “just how things are done here,” a habit of learning with real accountability.

What’s your first response to the idea of getting and giving behavioral feedback being a routine part of your culture? What one behavior rises to the top when you combine your own self-assessment with feedback from others? How will you model this practice so that your team feels safe and inspired to do the same? 7 steps for you and your leadership team
• Ask and reflect. Gather quick input from three to five colleagues on one behavior you can improve. Next, weigh it alongside your own priorities and the organization’s needs and performance review initiatives.
• Make it public. Share your chosen focus with your team so they can notice and support your progress.
• Check progress regularly. Once or twice a month, ask those same colleagues what they’ve observed and thank them for their input.
• Coach your team to do the same. Walk each senior leader through the process. Help them identify their behavior, seek input, and set a check-in plan.
• Embed feedback into leadership meetings. Start monthly leadership meetings with a five-minute “what I’m working on” round. Keep it light but consistent.
• Pair people up. Encourage leaders to choose an “accountability buddy” who will observe their shift and give real-time feedback.
• Capture and share wins. Create a shared document or quick Slack channel where leaders can post “small wins” and what they’ve noticed about themselves or others. As CEO, your behavior sets the tone inside your company. By modeling a clear, consistent cycle of input, reflection, action, and follow-up to improve your own behaviors, you create a culture that welcomes feedback and facilitates growth. When leaders at every level see you doing this—choosing your own focus, asking for input, acting on it, and looping back—they’re far more likely to follow suit. Throughout time, the practice becomes part of your organization’s DNA. Thus, your company culture becomes more adaptive, connected, and effective. All because you started with one well-chosen behavior, the courage to work on it openly, and the willingness to invite your team to join you.

The opinions expressed here by Inc.com columnists are their own, not those of Inc.com.
summary: The CEO's playbook for team feedback is a powerful tool that allows people to identify one specific behavior to improve themselves. This involves setting the tone at the top and allowing your team to respond to feedback without defensiveness. The process of stakeholder-centered coaching, pioneered by Marshall Goldsmith and colleagues, combines external feedback from those affected by your leadership with internal clarity about what matters most. Once you identify a specific behavior, share it publicly and follow up with check-in statements such as "I’ve been working on my communication," or "pause before responding to tough questions". These statements establish a clear culture that welcomes feedback and facilitates growth. The CEO's behavior sets the tone inside your company and encourages others to follow suit.
shortSummary: As CEO, CEO, can foster a cohesive, collaborative culture by encouraging team collaboration through integrating individual behavior into daily practices, creating a consistent, consistent culture.

scraped_sources.text:
At Marshall Goldsmith Stakeholder Centered Coaching® , we don’t just certify coaches. We equip you with a structured, results-driven methodology that guarantees measurable leadership growth. Our proven methodology helps you create lasting change for your clients so you can stand out, build a thriving coaching business, and elevate your credibility.
And you won’t be doing it alone. When you join our certification program, you become part of a global network of top coaches and mentors, all committed to your success. Because coaching isn’t just about what you know, it’s about the impact you deliver.
Want to learn more about Stakeholder Centered Coaching® and how it can transform your coaching practice? Let’s talk.
The process is simple, but not easy. Think of it as a 5-step approach.
1. Pick a leadership skill to improve.
2. Get buy-in from the stakeholders.
3. Use FeedForward to action plan.
4. Lead change with monthly involvement.
5. Measure changes in leadership effectiveness.
The research-based process ensures that you are continuously more effective in your coaching practice, guaranteed. Best of all, the habits you establish through the program will stay with you forever.
Become a Stakeholder Centered Coach today.
We are the world’s leading experts on executive coaching. For more than 30 years we’ve been pioneering the coaching field and paving the way for those who came after us. Our coaching process is so powerful that we guarantee improvement for our clients. Now you can, too.
Learn what took us decades of research & development to perfect.

Some of the following events are exclusively for our certified coaches. If you’d like to request a public event, webinar, or workshop, please email contact@mgscc.net.

argos_summary: The article explains how CEOs can foster a culture of continuous improvement by modeling stakeholder‑centered coaching—seeking feedback, setting a specific behavior to improve, and publicly sharing progress. It outlines a seven‑step process: gather input, choose a behavior, make it public, check progress, coach leaders, pair accountability buddies, and celebrate wins. By embedding short feedback rounds into leadership meetings and encouraging leaders to do the same, the practice becomes part of the organization’s DNA, leading to a more adaptive, connected, and effective culture.
